'''John L. Smith''' is an American attorney who has served in the [[United States Department of Justice]] (DOJ) as an [[assistant United States Attorney]], acting [[United States Attorney]], and as head of the department's [[Public Integrity Section]]. He was also the chief prosecutor at the [[Kosovo Specialist Chambers]], an international tribunal at [[The Hague]] tasked with investigating and prosecuting [[war crimes in the Kosovo War]].

In November 2022, [[Attorney General of the United States|U.S. Attorney General]] [[Merrick Garland]] appointed Smith an independent [[special counsel]], responsible for overseeing two preexisting DOJ criminal investigations into former president [[Donald Trump]]: an investigation regarding Trump's role in the [[January 6 United States Capitol attack|January 6 attack]] on the [[U.S. Capitol]], and an investigation into [[FBI investigation into Donald Trump's handling of government documents|mishandling of government records, including classified documents]].

==Early life and education==
Smith grew up in [[Clay, New York]], a suburb of [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]].<ref name=yost>{{cite news | access-date = November 19, 2022 | date = August 30, 2010 | url = https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-dojs-elite-public-integrity-unit-gets-new-leader-2010aug30-story.html | title = DOJ's elite Public Integrity unit gets new leader | newspaper = San Diego Union-Tribune | agency = Associated Press | first = Pete | last = Yost }}</ref><ref name=savage>{{Cite news |last1=Savage |first1=Charlie |last2=Feuer |first2=Alan |date=November 19, 2022 |title=In New Special Counsel, a Prosecutor Schooled in Corruption Cases |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/19/us/politics/jack-smith-trump-special-counsel.html|accessdate=November 21, 2022}}</ref> In 1987, he graduated from [[Liverpool High School]]<ref>{{cite news | url = https://eaglenewsonline.com/new/government/2022/11/18/liverpool-named-special-counsel-for-trump-investigation/ | access-date = November 19, 2022 | date = November 18, 2022 | title = Liverpool grad named special counsel to oversee Trump investigations | newspaper = Eagle News | first = Ashley M. | last = Casey}}</ref> where he played football and baseball.<ref name="Liverpool football">{{cite news |last1=Eisenstadt |first1=Marnie |title=How Jack Smith went from Liverpool football bench to a starring role in Trump investigation |url=https://www.syracuse.com/news/2022/12/how-jack-smith-went-from-liverpool-football-bench-to-a-starring-role-in-trumps-prosecution.html |access-date=December 14, 2022 |work=[[syracuse.com]] |date=December 14, 2022 |language=en}}</ref> He earned his [[Bachelor of Arts]] ''[[summa cum laude]]'' from the [[State University of New York at Oneonta]]<ref>{{cite web | access-date = November 19, 2022 | url = https://lawandcrime.com/trump/special-counsel-tapped-by-merrick-garland-to-investigate-trump-formerly-prosecuted-top-democrats-and-republicans/amp/ | website = Law & Crime | title = Special Counsel Tapped by Merrick Garland to Investigate Trump Formerly Prosecuted Top Democrats and Republicans | date = November 18, 2022 | first = Aaron | last = Keller }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Scott |first=Eugene |date=November 18, 2022 |title= Who is Jack Smith, special counsel in Trump criminal investigation? |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2022/11/18/trump-justice-department-mar-a-lago/ |access-date=November 18, 2022}}</ref> and his [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Harvard Law School]] in 1994.<ref name=savage/>

== Career ==
After graduating from law school, Smith joined the [[Manhattan District Attorney]]'s office, serving as [[Assistant District Attorney]]. He was a member of the [[sex crime]]s and [[domestic violence]] units of the DA's office.<ref name="specialist">{{Cite web |date=May 20, 2016 |title=Specialist Prosecutor |url=https://www.scp-ks.org/en/spo/specialist-prosecutor |access-date=November 18, 2022 |website=Kosovo Specialist Chambers & Specialist Prosecutor's Office |language=en | url-status =live | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20221118193247/https://www.scp-ks.org/en/spo/specialist-prosecutor | archive-date = November 18, 2022 }}</ref> He joined the [[United States Attorney's Office]] for the [[Eastern District of New York]] in 1999. As an [[assistant U.S. attorney]] at the [[Brooklyn]]-based office, he prosecuted the police officers who sodomized [[Abner Louima]], and secured the death penalty against [[Ronell Wilson]], who murdered two members of the [[New York Police Department]].<ref name=savage/><ref name=cnn/><ref name=WhoIs/>

From 2008 to 2010, Smith worked as Investigation Coordinator for the [[Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court|Office of the Prosecutor]] of the [[International Criminal Court]] in [[The Hague]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Jack Smith |url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-mdtn/jack-smith |website=United States Department of Justice |access-date=December 2, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221126014933/https://www.justice.gov/usao-mdtn/jack-smith |archive-date=November 26, 2022 |date=April 14, 2015 |quote=From 2008 to 2010, Jack served as Investigation Coordinator in the Office of the Prosecutor at the International Criminal Court (ICC) in the Hague, Netherlands. |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="WhoIs">{{cite web |last1=Feuer |first1=Alan |last2=Savage |first2=Charlie |title=Who Is Jack Smith, the New Special Counsel? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/18/us/politics/jack-smith-special-counsel-trump.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=December 8, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221207100244/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/18/us/politics/jack-smith-special-counsel-trump.html |archive-date=December 7, 2022 |date=November 18, 2022 |url-status=live}}</ref> In that position, he oversaw cases against government officials and militia members accused of war crimes and genocide.<ref name=savage/><ref name=cnn/> In 2010, Smith returned to the U.S. to become chief of the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]]'s [[Public Integrity Section]] (PIS).<ref name=yost/><ref name=WhoIs/> Among his first responsibilities was evaluating current investigations, and he recommended closing investigations into several members of Congress.<ref name=savage/>{{efn|Smith recommended closing investigations into Senator [[John Ensign]] and Representatives [[Tom DeLay]], [[Jerry Lewis (California politician)|Jerry Lewis]], and [[Alan Mollohan]].<ref name=savage/>}} He spent five years as chief of the PIS, where he prosecuted a variety of corruption cases, including those against [[Virginia Governor]] [[Bob McDonnell]], [[U.S. Representative]] [[Rick Renzi]], [[List of speakers of the New York State Assembly|New York Assembly Speaker]] [[Sheldon Silver]], and [[Jeffrey Alexander Sterling|Jeffrey Sterling]], a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] agent who shared national secrets.<ref name=politico/><ref name=WhoIs/>

In 2015, Smith became an assistant U.S. attorney in the [[United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee|Middle District of Tennessee]], at [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]].<ref name=npr/><ref name=WhoIs/> He became the Acting United States Attorney in March 2017 upon the resignation of David Rivera, and resigned effective September 2017 after the nomination of [[Donald Q. Cochran]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2017/08/04/jack-smith-resigns-nashville-federal-prosecutors-office/540429001/ |title=Jack Smith to resign from Nashville federal prosecutor's office |publisher=Tennessean.com |date=August 4, 2017 |accessdate=November 18, 2022}}</ref> Smith became the vice president and head of litigation for [[Hospital Corporation of America]] in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scp-ks.org/en/us-prosecutor-jack-smith-appointed-specialist-prosecutor|title=US Prosecutor Jack Smith appointed Specialist Prosecutor|date=May 4, 2018|website=Kosovo Specialist Chambers & Specialist Prosecutor's Office|accessdate=November 21, 2022}}</ref>

On May 7, 2018, Smith was named to a four-year term as chief prosecutor for the [[Kosovo Specialist Chambers]] in The Hague, investigating [[War crimes in the Kosovo War|war crimes]] committed in the [[Kosovo War]],<ref name=specialist/><ref name="cnn">{{Cite web |last1=Cohen |first1=Zachary |last2=Scannell |first2=Kara |last3=Herb |first3=Jeremy |last4=Polantz |first4=Katelyn |last5=Duster |first5=Chandelis |date=November 18, 2022 |title=Who is Jack Smith, the special counsel named in the Trump investigations |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/11/18/politics/jack-smith-special-counsel/index.html |access-date=November 19, 2022 |website=[[CNN]] |language=en}}</ref><ref name=npr>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2022/11/18/1137847204/who-is-doj-special-counsel-jack-smith|title=Who is DOJ Special Counsel Jack Smith?|first=Dustin|last=Jones|work=NPR|date=November 18, 2022|accessdate=November 18, 2022}}</ref> including the case of [[Salih Mustafa]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Berg |first=Stephanie van den |date=September 15, 2021 |title=Ex-rebel denies war crimes as Kosovo tribunal starts first trial |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ex-rebel-denies-war-crimes-kosovo-tribunal-opens-first-trial-2021-09-15/ |access-date=November 19, 2022}}</ref> He took up the post on September 11, 2018, and was appointed to a second term on May 8, 2022.<ref name=specialist/>

== United States special counsel ==
{{Main|Smith special counsel investigation}}
On November 18, 2022, [[United States Attorney General]] [[Merrick Garland]] appointed Smith [[special counsel]] to oversee the criminal investigations into [[Donald Trump]]'s actions regarding the [[January 6 United States Capitol attack]], and Trump's [[FBI investigation into Donald Trump's handling of government documents|handling and storage of government records, including classified documents]] at his [[FBI search of Mar-a-Lago|Mar-a-Lago estate]].<ref name=cnn/><ref name=politico>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/11/18/garland-to-appoint-special-counsel-for-trump-criminal-probes-00069451|title=Garland names Jack Smith special counsel for Trump criminal probes|website=POLITICO|date=November 18, 2022|accessdate=November 18, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Thrush |first1=Glenn |last2=Savage |first2=Charlie |last3=Haberman |first3=Maggie |last4=Feuer |first4=Alan |title=Garland Names Special Counsel for Trump Inquiries |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/18/us/politics/trump-special-counsel-garland.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=November 19, 2022 |date=November 18, 2022 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/appointment-special-counsel-0|title=Appointment of a Special Counsel|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice|date=November 18, 2022}}</ref> He will work initially from the Netherlands until he recovers from a fractured leg injured when he was struck by a scooter while cycling.<ref name=savage/>

== Awards ==
* US Department of Justice Director's Award<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |title=US Prosecutor Tapped to Head Up Kosovo War Crime Court |url=https://www.courthousenews.com/us-prosecutor-appointed-to-investigate-kosovo-war-crimes/ |access-date=November 18, 2022 |website=www.courthousenews.com |language=en-US}}</ref>
* US Attorney General's Award for Distinguished Service<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Gans |first=Jared |date=November 18, 2022 |title=Who is Special Counsel Jack Smith? |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/3742261-who-is-special-counsel-jack-smith/ |access-date=November 18, 2022 |website=The Hill |language=en-US}}</ref>
* Federal Bar Association's Younger Federal Attorney Award<ref name=":0" />
* Eastern District Association's Charles Rose Award<ref name=":1" />
* Henry L. Stimson Medal of the New York County Bar Association<ref name=":1" />
* Harvard Law School Wasserstein Fellowship<ref>{{Cite web |title=Past Wasserstein Fellows |url=https://hls.harvard.edu/wasserstein-fellows-program/past-wasserstein-fellows/ |access-date=November 18, 2022 |website=Harvard Law School |language=en-us}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Smith is a competitive [[Triathlon|triathlete]] despite not becoming a swimmer until he was in his mid-thirties.<ref>{{cite news | newspaper = The Wall Street Journal | title =Jack Smith Brings Broad Resume, Low Political Profile to High-Visibility Post | date =November 18, 2022 | first1=Aruna |last1=Viswanatha | first2= Sadie | last2= Gurman |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/jack-smith-brings-broad-resume-low-political-profile-to-high-visibility-post-11668810884 | access-date = November 19, 2022}}</ref><ref name=swimnac/> In July 2011, he married [[Katy Chevigny]],<ref>{{Cite magazine |year=2012 |title=Class Notes |magazine=[[Harvard Law Bulletin]] |volume=63 |page=58 |url=https://docplayer.net/94980938-Harvard-law-new-connections-between-theory-and-practice-bulletin-l-real-world-perspectives-and-hands-on-training-v.html |quote=On July 23, Jack Smith and Katy Chevigny were married on the banks of the St. Lawrence River in upstate New York by the Honorable Nicholas G. Garaufis. Smith is serving as the chief of the public integrity section of the U.S. Department of Justice in Washington, D.C., where the couple lives.}}</ref> a documentary filmmaker.<ref name=swimnac>{{Cite interview |title= Masters/Tri Q&A: Jack Smith |url= http://swimnac.com/masterstri-qa-jack-smith/ | access-date = November 20, 2022 | website = Nashville Aquatic Club | date= January 31, 2018 }}</ref> They have a daughter.<ref name=swimnac/> The couple has been living in the Netherlands since 2018.<ref name="Liverpool football"/>
